# lm intro

.left-code[
```{r}
meansum <- 
  dat %>%
  group_by(Diet) %>%
  summarise(mean = mean(Bodyweight))
lm1 <- lm(Bodyweight ~ Diet, #<<
          data = dat) #<< 
coefs <- coef(lm1)
```

$$y = b_0X_0 + b_1 X_1 + \epsilon$$
]

# lm intro - determining the coefficients


.left-code[
```{r}
Y <- dat$Bodyweight
X <- model.matrix(lm1)
beta <- solve(t(X) %*% X) %*% t(X) %*% Y
epsilon <- Y - t(beta) %*% t(X)
beta

```
]

.pull-right[
$$
\beta= (X^TX)^{âˆ’1} (X^TY)
$$

$\beta$ minimizes $$\sum(Y - \beta X)^2 = (Y-\beta X)(Y-\beta X)^T$$. 

predicting Y
$$\hat{Y} = X \beta = b_0X_0 + b_1X_1$$

residues
$$e = Y - X\beta$$ 

]

# lm intro - contrasts

.left-code[
```{r}
linfct <- rbind(
  chow = c(1, 0),
  hf = c(1, 1 )
  )
linfct %*% coef(lm1)
```
$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{chow} = b_0\cdot1 + b_1\cdot0\\
Y_{hf} = b_0\cdot1 + b_1\cdot1\\
\end{aligned}
$$
]

# lm intro - contrasts

.left-code[
```{r}
contrasts <- rbind(
  "chow - hf" = 
    linfct["chow",] - linfct["hf",] #<<
)
contrasts %*% coef(lm1)

```
$$

$$

# lm intro -  LSE standard error

.left-code[

```{r}
epsilon  <- resid(lm1)
sigma <- 
  sqrt(sum(epsilon ^2)/
         (length(epsilon ) -
            length(coef(lm1))) )

X <- model.matrix(lm1)
solve(t(X) %*% X) * sigma^2 #<<
vcov(lm1) #<<
```
]

.pull-left[
$$
\begin{aligned}
var(\hat{\beta}) &= var((X^\top X)^{-1}X^\top Y)\\
&= \cdots\\
&= \sigma^2 (X^\top X)^{-1}\\
with~~~ \sigma^2 &= \sum e^2 / (n-p)
\end{aligned}
$$
]

.footnote[LSE = least square estimate]
---

# lm intro - computing the test statistic

.left-code[
```{r}
std.error <- sqrt(diag(
  linfct %*% #<<
  vcov(lm1) %*% #<<
  t(linfct))) #<<
t.statistic <- 
  linfct%*%coef(lm1)/std.error #<<
t.statistic

std.error <- sqrt(diag(
  contrasts %*%
    vcov(lm1) %*%
    t(contrasts)))
t.statistic <- 
  contrasts %*% coef(lm1) / std.error
t.statistic

```
]

.pull-right[
$$
t_i = \frac{\beta_i}{se(\beta_i)}
$$
]

# Yeast dataset analysis using linear models

Protein level model

$y_{il} = \alpha_i + \epsilon_{il}$

where $y_{il}$ the intensity of the protein in condition $i$ and replicate $l$.
and $i \in \{ethanol, glucose\}$ and $\epsilon_{il} \in N(0,s_e)$.

Than the protein fold change can be computed by:

$$\textrm{fc}_{glucose - ethanol} = \alpha_{glucose} - \alpha_{ethanol}$$

---

# Peptide and Protein level models

Series of publication showing that modelling __protein fold changes__<br/>
by using __peptide level intensities__<br/>
is more __sensitive__ and __specific__ than using __aggregated protein intensities__.


_Peptide measurements are repeated measurements of the same protein._


.footnote[Suomi and Elo 2017 PMID: 28724900</br>
Geomine, Gevaert and Clement 2016 PMID: 26566788]

---

# Yeast analysis - peptide level models

Linear Mixed Effect Models

$$
y = X\beta + Zu + \epsilon
$$

Where $y$ is a column vector, the outcome variable; $X$ the matrix of predictor variables (design matrix); $b$ is a column vector of the fixed-effects regression coefficients,
$Z$ is the design matrix for the random effects (describes the covariance structure of the data) and $u$ is a column vector of the random effect coefficients, $\epsilon$ is the column vector of the residuals.

.footnote[For more details see e.g.: [UCLA IDRE](https://stats.idre.ucla.edu/other/mult-pkg/introduction-to-linear-mixed-models/)]

---

# Yeast analysis - peptide level models

mixed effects linear model for batch $p2370$ and $p2691$
- fixed effects : condition
- random effects : peptides

$$y_{ijk} = \alpha_i + a_j + \epsilon_{ijk}$$
with  $i \in \{ethanol, glucose\}$,  $k \in {1:t}$ (nr replicates),  and $j$ iterates over all peptides of a protein.

and where: $$a_j \propto N(0, s_a); ~ \epsilon_{ijk} \propto N(0, s_e)$$

The protein fold change can be computed by:

$$\textrm{fc}_{glucose - ethanol} = \alpha_{glucose} - \alpha_{ethanol}$$

.footnote[model specification adapted from Geomine, Gevaert and Clement 2016 PMID: 26566788]

---

# Yeast analysis - both batches - model 1

mixed effects linear model
- fixed effects : condition, batch
- random effects : peptides

$$y_{ijkl} = \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_{ij} +  a_k + \epsilon_{ijkl}$$
with  $i \in \{ethanol, glucose\}$, $j \in \{p2370, p2691\}$,<br/>
$\gamma_{ij}$ i.e. $ij = \{$ ethanol:p2370, ethanol:p2691, glucose:p2370, glucose:p2691 $\}$ ,
$l \in {1:t}$ (replicate) and $k$ iterates over all peptides of a protein.

and where: 
$$a_k \propto N(0, s_a); ~ \epsilon_{ijkl} \propto N(0, s_e)$$
---

# Yeast analysis - both batches - model 1

The protein fold change can be computed by:
$$
\begin{aligned}
\textrm{fc}_{glucose - ethanol} &= \alpha_{glucose} - \alpha_{ethanol}\\
\textrm{fc}_{p2370- p2691} &= \beta{p2370} - \alpha_{p2691}\\
\textrm{fc}_{glucose:p2370 - ethanol:p2370} &= ... \\
\textrm{fc}_{glucose:p2691 - ethanol:p2691} &= ...\\
\textrm{fc}_{interaction} &= \textrm{fc}_{glucose:p2370 - ethanol:p2370} - \textrm{fc}_{glucose:p2691 - ethanol:p2691}\\
\end{aligned}
$$
---

# Yeast analysis - both batches - model 2

mixed effects linear model
- fixed effects : condition 
- random effects : batch, peptides


$$y_{ijkl} = \alpha_i +  a_j + b_k + \epsilon_{ijkl}$$
where  $i \in \{ethanol, glucose\}$,  $j \in \{p2370, p2691\}$, $l \in {1:t}$ (replicate), and $k$ iterates over all peptides of a protein and 

$$a_j \propto N(0, s_a); ~ b_k \propto N(0, s_b); ~ \epsilon_{ijkl} \propto N(0, s_e)$$


The protein fold change can be computed by:

$$\textrm{fc}_{glucose - ethanol} = \alpha_{glucose} - \alpha_{ethanol}$$
---

# Conclusions


- Linear models allow for
  - calculation of fold changes, but also of differences between fold changes
  - modelling of interactions between factors 
- Modelling on peptide level potentially is more sensitive and specific than modelling on protein level
- If measurements are correlated i.e. multiple peptides of a protein, than mixed effect linear models can be used
